channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kerry Stops in Paris Ahead of Iran Nuclear Talks in Vienna
item.description: The secretary of state sought to close ranks with an important ally before joining the negotiations over Tehran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Assassin’s Creed Meets the French Revolution, and the Left Rebels Again
item.description: Critics say the video game’s latest version is excessively sympathetic to the monarchy and disrespectful to the revolutionaries who overthrew King Louis XVI.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: An image from the video game Assassin's Creed Unity, set in Paris during the French Revolution, which some critics says portrays the revolutionaries as bloodthirsty murderers.

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood Leader Arrested in Egypt
item.description: With the arrest of the last senior Brotherhood leader not in prison, the government’s main channel of communication with the group was closed off.
item.dc:creator: By MERNA THOMAS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Fiction Echoes Political Fact in Hong Kong TV Drama
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong residents tuned in Wednesday to watch the first episode of “The Election,” a 15-part series depicting a political tussle that bears a remarkable resemblance to the current turmoil on the city’s streets.
item.category: Chinese University of Hong Kong, The
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Swedish Court Rejects Appeal by Julian Assange
item.description: Mr. Assange, the founder of Wikileaks, had argued that an order for his detention could not be enforced and infringed on his civil rights.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The Ecuadorean Embassy in London where Julian Assange has been living since June 2012 in an attempt to avoid extradition to Sweden, where he faces allegations of sexual assault.

item.title: Peace Talks in Myanmar Jeopardized by Killing of Rebels
item.description: Ethnic minority groups in the country said that the talks on a cease-fire were in danger after at least 23 rebel cadets died in an attack by the military.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sri Lanka’s President to Seek Unprecedented Third Term
item.description: President Mahinda Rajapaksa announced his intention to hold a vote two years ahead of schedule after his governing party unanimously endorsed the move.
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Lens Blog: Uprooted Syrian Youths Express Themselves
item.description: Brendan Bannon worked with refugee children in Jordan to help them use photography to document their environment and express themselves.
item.category: Do You See What I See
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By ANIA BARTKOWIAK

item.title: Video Shows French ISIS Fighters Calling for Attacks in France
item.description: The seven-minute clip, released by an Islamic State affiliate, appears to be part of an intensifying effort to recruit young Europeans.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: News Analysis: Japan’s Economic Woes Cast New Doubt on Abenomics
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s stimulus program faces opposition from a powerful ministry, while some economists say it doesn’t go far enough in restructuring the economy.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: The Struggle to Erase Saudi Extremism
item.description: More needs to be done to confront the Islamic State — a danger to the country’s survival as well as to its assertion that Islam is a peaceful faith.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JANET BRESLIN SMITH and CARYLE MURPHY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: East-West Meets Far North
item.description: It’s no wonder that the Norwegians above the Arctic Circle are nervous about the prospect of a new Cold War.
item.dc:creator: By JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Man Stabs 7 Hospital Workers to Death in China, Police Say
item.description: The suspect, a 27-year-old employee at the military hospital, famous for gatherings of Communist Party leaders, had no known motive, according to a police statement.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Chief of Ferry Company in South Korea Is Given 10-Year Jail Sentence
item.description: Kim Han-sik, 71, the head of the Chonghaejin Marine Company, was convicted of accidental homicide and embezzlement over the sinking of the ferry Sewol in April.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: China Detains U.S. Aid Worker Who Assisted North Koreans
item.description: Peter Hahn, who is 73 and escaped from the North years ago, is suspected of embezzlement and possession of fraudulent receipts, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Deadly School Van Crash Revives Concerns Over Safety Standards
item.description: A collision with a commercial truck hauling sand in Shandong Province killed 11 kindergartners and the driver.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: North Korea Threatens to Conduct Nuclear Test
item.description: North Korea said the actions would be in response to a United Nations committee’s recommendation to prosecute North Korean leaders for rights violations.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: U.N. Security Council Calls to Block Recruiting of Militants
item.description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a statement asking all countries to thwart foreign-born militants who have sought to join extremist groups.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Malawi: Students Demand Teachers Be Paid So Classes Can Resume
item.description: About 500 schoolchildren broke classroom windows and damaged cars on Wednesday to protest a strike by their teachers in Malawi’s commercial capital, Blantyre.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: North Korea: Plutonium Extraction May Be Restarting, Institute Says
item.description: An American research institute reported Wednesday that North Korea might be preparing to reprocess spent nuclear fuel to extract weapons-grade plutonium at its main nuclear complex north of its capital, Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ebola’s Economic Cost Re-Examined
item.description: The World Bank chief economist for Africa said the cost may be $3 billion or $4 billion, not the worst-case outcome of more than $32 billion.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: A Sudden Schism Emerges Between Abe and the Bank of Japan Governor
item.description: Japan’s prime minister has postponed a planned tax increase championed by Haruhiko Kuroda, the bank’s governor, in a sharp break from their partnership.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Haruhiko Kuroda, the Bank of Japan governor, at a news conference on Wednesday in Tokyo. He supports a tax increase that the prime minister wants postponed.

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Gunmen Kill Minnesota Man
item.description: Gunmen shot and killed a Somali-American from Minnesota who had left his job to help the fledgling city government in Mogadishu with urban planning and drainage systems.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Urges Arab World to Denounce Islamic State
item.description: The United Nations’ top human rights official on Tuesday called on the Security Council to back efforts to overturn the extremist group’s “ideology of violence.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Cartagena Journal: A Hammer Comes Down in Colombia on an Honor for Britain
item.description: An activist took things into his own hands after a historical marker commemorating the death of British and American troops was unveiled in a ceremony attended by Prince Charles.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Colombians dressed up for Independence Day, including one as the one-legged military hero Blas de Lezo.
